results.title: Calamity Jane
results.creator_credit: William Jacobs, Warner Bros Pictures and David Butler
results.brief_description: This musical western has Doris Day as Calamity Jane and Howard Keel as Wild Bill Hickcock. Calamity Jane comes in from the ‘Windy city’ after finding a star attraction for the local saloon. As she is taken by the ‘Deadwood Stage’ to the ‘Black hills of Dakota’, she meets Wild Bill Hickock, her ‘Secret love’. This is the Wild West in a spectacular musical.
results.creator_credit_for_label: William Jacobs, Warner Bros Pictures and David Butler

results.title: Cal
results.creator_credit: Enigma Productions, Stuart Craig, David Puttnam and Pat O'Connor
results.brief_description: Cal, played by John Lynch in a very impressive film debut, is an unemployed 19 year-old Catholic who is unwillingly drawn into the dangerous and violent world of the IRA, becoming an accomplice in the murder of a Protestant policeman. When he gets a job on the lonely farm where the dead man’s widow Marcella, played flawlessly by Helen Mirren, lives with her in-laws, Cal finds himself drawn to her. It is the start of a passionate affair between the guilt-ridden youth and the unhappy woman, a moving romance that ultimately ends in tragedy. This compelling story gains considerably in its dramatic impact from the superbly realized background of the bitter sectarian violence in Northern Ireland. Based on the original novel by Bernard MacLaverty and featuring the beautifully haunting music of Mark Knopfler (Dire Straits).

results.title: Cake decorating with Robyn Hamilton. Pt. 2
results.brief_description: Robyn Hamilton continues with her demonstration on cake decorating techniques. This part is for the more advanced student on the art of lace, frilling, insertion, extension.

results.title: Cairo: as told by Youssef Chahine
results.creator_credit: Mustapha Abdel Aziz, Misr International Films, Miroirs and Youssef Chahine
results.brief_description: Personal documentary essay on the city of Cairo by renowned Egyptian filmmaker Youssef Chahine. Director of over forty films, Chahine is renowned for his diverse styles and often controversial subject matter. “Cairo as told by Youssef Chahine” began as a commission by French TV for the news series Envoye Special. Using his unique sense of artistic digression, Chahine begins the film by poking fun at conventional travelogue imagery of Cairo, before going on to explore, from a deeply personal perspective, the contemporary political, religious and social life of the city he loves. The film was banned in Egypt for showing too much dirt.

results.title: Cairo station = Bab el hadid
results.brief_description: Renowned Egyptian director Youssef Chahine established his international reputation with “Cairo Station” after it screened at the Berlin Film Festival. Focusing on a group of marginalised luggage carriers and soft-drink sellers who live in abandoned traincars, Chahine posits Cairo’s main railroad station as a microcosm of Egyptian society. A crippled newspaper dealer (played powerfully by Chahine himself), falls in love with a beautiful but indifferent lemonade seller who is engaged to the muscular and virile leader of the luggage-carriers. Swept away by his obsessive desire, the crippled man kidnaps the object of his passion, with terrible consequences. Into this story of doomed sexual obsession amongst a shadowy underclass, Chahine weaves glaring economic disparity, union activity, and other politically charged motifs. The work of Fritz Lang and the genres of film-noir and neo-realism are often cited as influences on the film. In Arabic with English subtitles.

results.title: Caged fury (D)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Adventure parade”.
WARNING: CONTAINS VISUALLY DISTURBING IMAGES Man’s capture and training of wild African beasts. The animals are seen in their native surroundings and the continual struggle for survival is depicted in scenes of fighting and killing. Shows the animals being trapped and shipped abroad, and the training methods through which they gradually adapt themselves to a new life.

results.title: Cage/Cunningham
results.creator_credit: Elliot Caplan, La Sept and Cunningham Dance Foundation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Merce Cunningham Dance Company = Cunningham Dance Foundation”.
Feature length documentary portrait tracing the history of the collaboration of choreographer, Merce Cunningham, and composer, John Cage, which spanned nearly fifty years beginning at the Cornish Institute of Allied Arts in Seattle, Washington. In telling the story of Cunningham and Cage, award winning filmmaker and Cunningham collaborator, Elliot Caplan, utilizes candid footage of their activities around the world since 1983, rare footage from the Cunningham and Cage archives, and interviews with principal figures involved in the collaboration. Caplan’s daily contact with Cage and Cunningham has inspired a revealing and sensitive portrait of two men whose spirit of adventure and iconoclastic thinking have helped to revolutionize life, as well as art in the twentieth century. Includes interviews with Nam June Paik, Robert Rauschenberg, Carolyn Brown, Viola Farber and Rudolf Nureyev. Choreography by Merce Cunningham. Music by John Cage. Reference: http://www.merce.org/filmvideo.html

results.title: Cafe and Boxes
results.creator_credit: Sydney Dance Company and Geoffrey Nottage
results.brief_description: Two dance films based on productions conceived and performed by the Sydney Dance Company. “A day in the life of a Darling cafe” is the theme of ‘Cafe’ (62mins. 1995), written and choreographed by dancers Paul Mercurio and Kim Walker. The production resembles a mix between a serious dance work and a satirical cabaret piece and is a behind-the-froth study of cafe society. Music by Brett Cabot and Colin Newham. ‘Boxes’ (60mins. 1985) was conceived by Iva Davies, Bob Kretschmer and Graeme Murphy as a dance work which was first performed by the Sydney Dance Company and the band ‘Icehouse’ at the Sydney Opera House on November 7, 1985.

Music by Brett Cabot and Colin Newham. ‘Boxes’ (60mins. 1985) was conceived by Iva Davies, Bob Kretschmer and Graeme Murphy as a dance work which was first performed by the Sydney Dance Company and the band ‘Icehouse’ at the Sydney Opera House on November 7, 1985.

results.title: Cafe
results.brief_description: This first film of writer, actor, director Craig Hoogendoorn, revolves around the cafe conversations of three groups of people - the lovers in the midst of a breakup, the male whining to the female about his ex-girlfriend’s behaviour and the three friends celebrating single life. Shot in black and white the camera plays back and forth between the three groups, catching their conversations in mid-flight. Witty and technically faultless, the film is a promising debut for this young Canberra based filmmaker.
